question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Addiction does not discriminate, more hugs=less drugs, applied information from guest speakers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a different approach to viewing substance abuse disorders. I also learned about various aspects to alcoholism and addiction. I learned that the most efficient way to learn about something is to hear first hand accounts (we commonly had speakers in class).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the physiology, biology, emotional, and social factors of addiction. I learned many models of addiction rehabilitation, such as the moral model and the public health model. We had an overview of the history of drugs relating to alcohol and drugs. Lastly, we talked to several recovering addicts and read memoirs, developing a realistic view of addiction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning about addiction form a multitude of lenses was so fascinating and fun. For example, learning about the psychology, social, and biological factors was engaging and fulfilling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Topic sensitivity

- Collaborative skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I thought about drugs and addiction in a non-judgmental manner, I learned about how substance abuse works with mental illness, and I learned how to be creative with my projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a deeper understanding of addiction and substance abuse through listening to people who experienced it firsthand. I learned how addiction is a disease and cannot be overcome with sheer willpower.   I learned that addiction does not discriminate, and anyone with a brain can get addicted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the physical mechanisms of addiction as well as the social aspects of addiction. I learned a lot about the different ways people can get treatment and how there are multiple access issues to obtaining treatment. Additionally, I learned about the personal stories of many who have suffered from addiction and how we can learn from them. This course was life changing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-less judgement towards others
-formation and nature of addiction
-how addiction can affect a life

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed an immense amount of knowledge regarding the complexities of drug addiction, recovery, neurological underpinnings, legal frameworks, and ongoing stigmatization surrounding addiction. Additionally, I feel that I gained a ton of insight regarding how I can better approach caring for family members or close friends struggling with their own addictive tendencies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course allowed me to see addiction from a new perspective. I have seen family lost due to substance abuse, and being able to see the neurological effect that it has on a person, tangling itself into the individual, I was able to learn how to help someone rather than being judgemental. Dr. Rezvani had us go through a detox, withdrawing ourselves from a certain substance. Not only were we placed into the shoes of the addict, but we were able to express our emotions by journaling our process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Some specific things I learned were the biological basis of addiction--with how certain drugs affect our brain chemistry--and the social stigmas surrounding addiction and those with addiction issues. The single most important lesson I feel that I took from this class is that addiction can genuinely impact anyone and that it is a disease, not a choice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think about addiction through new perspectives in this class. Instead of just focusing on the neurobiology of addiction, Dr. Rezvani discussed the often overlooked social aspects. Through the lectures, guest speakers, field trip and projects, this class enriched my knowledge of addiction and allowed me to fundamentally understand that all addicts do not fit a "mold" or stereotype. Dr. Rezvani's famous "More hugs, Less drugs" will stick with me for the rest of my life, as will the skills I have gained through the debate, individual + group projects and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Mechanisms of action of certain drugs such as alcohol, marijuana, etc.
2. What addiction can feel like or present itself like in an individual
3. How addiction is a disease, just like diabetes, and should not be stigmatized

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the basics of psychological research, an area I had no exposure too, specifically becoming aware of what makes a research study credible, valid, and impactful. I also learned that much of an individual's life is shaped by early childhood experiences, and that antisocial behavior development can have its strongest roots in early childhood. The final most transformative perspective I gained insight to is the injustices of our criminal justice system that perpetually disadvantages certain minority groups, and leaves individuals worse off than before. Overall, the course renewed my passion for justice reform and child policy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to usse statistics and psychological techniques to make casual correlations abut risk factors for certain antisocial behaviors and crimes. Multiple topics such as sexual abuse, socioeconomic status, abuse, trauma, and genetics were all topics we analyzed andd research with links to the criminal justice system. We identified prejudice and other issues within the criminal justice system as well as determined how police misconduct unequally threatens people of color, women, and those in low-income communities. We developed these skills through reading peer-reviewed journals, news articles, listening to experts, and discussing our thoughts in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to select research studies for a paper from accredited psychology sources. I also improved on my debating skills, as I had the opportunity to practice debating twice. Finally, I became a more worldly thinker, as I learned to argue things from a variety of perspectives in the debate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Great researching skills
Better methods to present debates
Group work

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The trajectory towards crime that starts prenatal and how every stage in a child’s development can have societal and familial risk factors, race and crime, reproductive justice

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight in this course including antisocial behaviors. I learned how different risk factors can contribute to a person's actions and that early intervention is crucial. Not only did I learn how to properly debate a topic, but to listen to the other side's opinions and ideas.

response_text: I think the most important insight we discussed in the class was the significance of prevention of risk factors influencing youth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest skill I learned through this class was how to empirically support arguments and debate topics! A second skill I learned was how to digest potentially politically polarizing information. A third skill I learned was how to create a scientific paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We not only learned how criminal behavior is developed in the personal capacities of psychology, but also the social implications and actions that lead to forcing people into crime. It is truly looking at the humanitarian nature of criminology, not just crime as a dehumanized example of human detriment and fault.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Risk factors for developing antisocial behaviors and science-based interventions to moderate those factors
Knowledge of the historically-based systems of discrimination that marginalized communities still struggle with today (e.g. slavery's connection to modern-day prisons)
How law and politics can hinder and even oppose progress (e.g. the state allocating resources in prison based on laws and not clinical best practice)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: PSY-767-01L : APPL CORREL AND REGRESS ANALY.PSY-767-01L.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment in this class was stellar. Lectures were well organized and clear, carefully scaffolding concepts so that we were able to understand not only how, but why each approach was to be used. Assignment struck the right balance of being calibrated to our current knowledge level while stretching our skills in each technique in a way that made each assignment time well spent. Labs and assignments were formatted in a way that promoted being able to get the support we needed and build our expertise in R as well. The feedback we got every week on assignments was amazing, and critical for us to be able to learn regression at a level that we will be able to actually use it in our research. The grading approach strongly supplemented this quality feedback emphasis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: From my personal perspective, this class was stimulating largely due to the well-designed assignments and the unique submission process. Madeline's method of having us upload corrected versions of our assignments to the system encouraged a more efficient learning environment. This approach allowed us to learn from our mistakes without fear, promoting a deeper understanding and mastery of the material. This method of iterative learning and feedback should definitely be continued to enhance intellectual stimulation for future classes.

response_text: This course is exceptionally well-structured, particularly in how assignments are designed and executed. The unique submission process, where you can revise and resubmit your work, really supports your learning. It allows you to understand your mistakes and learn from them without pressure.
